comments.commentBody: Not any Christian, just fundamentalist.

If we thought the Republican primary race was spectacular, gladiatorial entertainment, now we can enjoy the interesting, inevitable "squirmishes" during the process to appoint a new Supreme Court justice.

Sorry, Bob, but if you are in real danger of losing out to an "illegal" for a job, you have even bigger problems than not having a job. The jobs left for you or the "illegals" are not much better than begging. The GOP and its fellow-travelers in service of the 1% have assured you of a permanent place at the bottom of the ladder whether you have a job or not. You're stuck.

Better and better for fewer and fewer.

"The American people already weighed in on who they want to decide on the Supreme Court nomination. In 2008, and again, in 2012. Have these Republicans absolutely no shame, whatsoever?"
Obama is "the other", to the Republicans. A black usurper with no legitimate claim to power. The Republican Party is a far greater threat to the stability of our country than North Korea, Russia, ISIS, and Al Qaeda, rolled into one.

Yes, Obama is right about the Constitution being clear about his right to nominate a new justice. But that's only according to the "dead" Constitution. According to the "living" Constitution, which the GOP suddenly seem to favor, Obama is all but compelled to leave the nomination to the next president.

Bork received a hearing. Completely different. A more accurate comparison would be for the GOP to allow Obama to put forth a radical left wing nominee. Then the GOP could look through the trash of the nominee in the middle of the night to find anything they could against the nominee. (which is what happened with Bork)

It's good to see what the other side is saying, even if it is nonsense.
The Democrats had Bork pushed down their throats and a democratic senate soundly defeated him. The same will happen if Obama courses to far left. It is what is SUPPOSED to happen per our constitution.

But to say the Democrats let the genie out of the bottle, or would have done the same to W is off point for the former and impossible to prove for the latter. The concern many of us have is that there are too many people who are making up some absurd case, which is what the Republicans are prone to do politically speaking. Then complete anti-constitutional nonsense like saying Obama can't nominate a judge is repeated over and over by fools. Geico should do a commercial where they say "if you're a Republican, this is just what you do". This has become the Republican way, and sadly it is why even those of us who lean slightly to the right on many issues cannot support the party.

The truth is the Founders created laws that beg for compromise. We have a President on one end and a Senate on the other. The judge, as far as I see it, should be end up in the middle. And you know what? A judge that actually has to think about the law from the middle is what most of us want anyway. Scalia, as much as he was a whatever you call him, simply tortured logic in the way he went about Heller. He was a partisan and it's time to stop nominating partisans on either side.

@Rohit
Kim Davis wasn't victimized, she is a bigot who tried to exploit the power of her office to run a public office according to that bigotry.

The Constitution is also "pretty clear" that Congress makes laws and the President has to "take care" to see that they are enforced - which President Obama, sadly, has refused to do when it comes to our immigration laws. This President has gone around Congress repeatedly to try to change laws that he could not get past Congress. Now Congress is biting back. I was not a fan of Scalia and would prefer to see more judges like Kennedy and fewer like Scalia, Thomas, Ginsburg and Breyer (whose votes can be predicted in advance). But, if RBG had died in the last year of Bush's second term, there is no way that Democrats would have let Bush appoint her successor. Everyone knows that. The outrage is -- as always -- selective. And let's remember that the Supreme Court nominating process was politicized first by Democrats in the 1980s. They started this nonsense with Bork. And they won the battle. But they lost the war because now all nominations are decided on mostly partly-line votes. Democrats let the genie out of the bottle with Bork and there's no going back.
Has he come for your guns yet?

This coming from the Constitutional law Adjunct who questioned whether the Supreme Court had the authority to review the Affordable Care Act. Sometimes I think this President forgets what he says. But, it is his role to nominate Justices and Judges and for the Senate to give its advice and consent. I've scanned the Constitution and nowhere does it say he's supposed to not nominate during an election year. If someone finds that in the document, please correct me.

More than insulting. It borders on treason ... these nitwits are publicly defying the Commander-in-Chief. Were they members of the military (precious few were), they'd be in the brig, or worse.

And how many elections? If the president is black, it doesn't count, or maybe in their eyes, he's only 3/5 of a president.

This has to be one of the lowest, most disgraceful periods of American history, right up there with the McCarthy era.

It's insulting to hear Senator McConnell say, "the American people should have a voice" in selecting the next justice. We had a voice! Twice. And we chose Obama as our Appointer in Chief. As for Senator Grassley--his home state is where Obama had his first big win. During the lead up to the historic Iowa 2008 caucuses, I spent time trudging around with a clipboard in the snow and ice, and the issue of Supreme Court appointments was definitely something Iowans cared about. They made their views clear, as did so many others in 08/12. So my Republican friends, how many elections does it take to hear our "voice" ?

Ms. Clinton is a proven war 'hawk' and would already have us deeply involved in Syria. She has proven time and time again that her judgment respecting military affairs is just too dangerous to be trusted or prudent. For examples: No fly zone in Syria directly confronting the Russians/Syrians and the Iranians and she  voted for the invasion of Iraq, just to name a couple You wanna talk about running up a national debt? Let's talk about another President that just can't wait to start a war just like GWB. If I had a choice between a war hawk and a guy who wants to run up the debt to help all Americans here at home, yeah, I'll take Senator Sanders any day of the week and twice on Sunday.

"Bernie is a fine man...[but we]... have too much debt and deficits to resolve first before moving forward."

Exactly. That's where the Republicans have the advantage. Let's face it: Hillary would run up the deficit even worse than Bernie, since she would have at least an outside chance of actually passing legislation; Bernie would do nothing but give angry speeches – which at least wouldn't raise the national debt.

Paying down debt isn't glamorous, which is precisely why that part of Keynesian economics has never been as widely embraced as the "prime the pump" part. But a lot of Americans think we need to do that. National debt has nearly doubled since Obama took office -- not his fault, really, since the debt has been jumping ever since Reagan took office. The fact remains: national debt has doubled since Obama took office, and I don't think voters will pick a candidate who's likely to either (1) accomplish nothing at all (Bernie); or (2) run up the debt at an even higher pace (Hillary). I think voters are going to do what they nearly always do after one party has held the White House for two terms: toss that party out and let the other one have a crack at it.
Because extremists on the left do want to take their guns away.

A Mexican's culture more closely mirrors the ideology of the Republican than it does the Democrats. Once naturalized, the newly minted Americans, no longer needing the Democrats support, will steadily effect their second migration, that to the right of American politics.

Hispanic cultures are rife with homophobia, misogyny and racism. Trump would be embraced as the second coming should he be a Mexican politician running for the PRI's nomination.

@Theodore --

Mr. Trump is proposing a $9 - $12 trillion decrease (over 10 years) in Federal tax revenues, mostly benefiting the wealthiest. How's he going to pay for that? He's promising not to tinker with Social Security or Medicare. He's promising to round up and deport some 11 million people, including their U. S. citizen children. How's he going to pay for that? He's promising to double-down on military readiness and escalate the fight against ISIL. How's he going to pay for that? He's promising to repeal Obamacare and replace it with something more "fantastic." How's he going to pay for that?

Theodore, take my word for it (or not), Mr. Trump is making a ton of meaningless promises -- even more and more incoherently than Mr. Saunders (who, at least, has a plan for how he might achieve his agenda after the "revolution") -- that he knows he cannot keep and which he probably has no intention of keeping in any case. It's all just bluster; all of it. Don't be fooled.

pls tell us where the Constitution says that Congress must hold hearings.
It doesn't.

I have a better idea. How about President Obama really shows what a "work across the isle" kind of guy he is and he nominates a conservative judge in Scalia's mold! Wow! Talk about political ju-jitsu! You could get behind that, right? Right? Hello??

I was unaware that the process of politics now requires that you do everything the opposition requires, or else any problems,s are all your fault. It is, frankly, embarrassing that we even gave to have discussions at this level.

@Jeff
I won't hold my breath waiting for you to suggest that a GOP president nominate a liberal.

Given the six major cases on the Supreme-Court’s pipeline, a Senate gridlock to filibuster a candidacy the Republicans don’t like would be of grave concern. The reason: a 4-to-4 vote split in most cases would result in justice delayed, and likely in justice denied.

This is the time for President Obama to prevent another bitter partisan war by extending an olive branch to Senator Charles Grassley and moderate Republicans.

I am confident Judge Jane Kelly would be the perfect candidate. She was confirmed 96 to 0 in her appointment to the Appeals Court with the unwavering support of no other than Senator Grassley who chaired the Senate Judiciary Committee.

For President Obama, Plan B would be Judge Adalberto Jordan who was confirmed to the Appeals Court by 94 votes to 5 with the support of 41 Republicans.

Both candidates would give President Obama an opportunity to strike common grounds by helping the GOP senators to demonstrate some courage and save face. Those who wish to maintain partisanship over patriotism would be in a Catch-22 situation, considering the high GOP-vote score achieved by each candidate in the latest confirmation.

I just wish the narrative of the debate was focused more on innovative options for mutual gains.
If Republicans in Congress won't do their job, we should fire them and get willing replacements.

Gorgon, please point to the clause of the Constitution where it states that the Senate is obligated to either hold hearings or to vote on a nominee. We strict constructionists out here would really appreciate your legal acumen on this point...
If Obama were capable of this, we'd not have suffered gridlock under his presidency.  He is incapable of appointing a moderate.
The Republicans invoke the Constitution all the time. When is suits them. Otherwise, out the window!

Republican representatives are doing exactly that: representing their constituents. Most do not want to allow another liberal jurist on the court. Why do you have a problem if they decide not to hold a vote for any nominee of President Obama?

Trash = pollution = reduced quality of life; that simple. When will people get it that our proliferate ways are harming the environment with huge and unseen (out-of-sight-out-of-mind) costs. Plastic being the worst scourge. Sigh
The Republicans' delay tactics might end up hurting their party, as more Democrats will be motivated to vote in the upcoming Presidential election when they realize what's at stake.

@VR,
Do I gather that you've save me the trouble of explaining some of this?

@HapinOregon,
Thanks for the reminders. The Treasury's a good example.

@John,
With respects, I know that the Senate holds the hearings, i.e., the Senate Judiciary Committee. But, what I'm talking about is McConnell's 'no' to hearings before the elections are over, no matter who Obama suggests to replace Scalia--period.

By the same token, I'm still not aware that governors are meant to have any input.

2-17-16@12:04 am

A constitutional scholar ought to have known that citizens gain their representation, and thus escape tyranny (to the extent that they do so), via the U.S. Congress rather than the makeup of the Supreme Court. The courts, and especially the Supreme Court, play a different role, upholding the rule of law based on its fundamental principles and history. Scalia was happy to play that card when it suited his preferred position on a case and then, apparently, to discard it for the same reason. Let's hope President Obama nominates a true jurist to help raise the Court above such cynical expedience.
There is such a contest, only it takes place on Saturday and is not shown on TV.

Why are dog shows being reported in the Sports section?  These dogs are not competing against each other athletically. They are not being bred, like horses, to be faster or better according to some physical measurement. If they are being bred to follow some ancient standard, then there should be a contest to see which retriever retrieves best, which terrier is the best ratter, etc. This would at least add some interesting substance to the current format, which is nothing more than a vapid beauty pageant!
